utterances: Greg Gause is a U.S.
academic and a Middle East specialist.
Watching the news in another Arab country and seeing what's happening on the street gives you a sense of what you can do.
Everything that I read in Saudi Arabia, media, the blogs, Facebook postings, people were focused on Tunisia, but they're obsessed with Egypt.
This is news, says Eman Al Nafjan, who writes a popular blog here.
She explains that most Saudis don't watch Al-Jazeera.
The government considers its broadcast anti-Saudi, but lots of Saudis are tuning in now.
Everybody's watching here.
Did you hear, did you see - that sort of thing.
Do you think that it will change the way people think in Saudi Arabia after having spent all these days watching a street protest in Cairo and Alexandria and across the country?
Definitely.
Especially if they succeed in creating a democracy and not having another Islamic revolution, just as in Iran.
It would change everybody's perception of what Arabs can do.
If pressed for a model, many site Turkey, a successful democracy with a government led by conservative Muslims.
Saudi Arabia appears insulated from any immediate challenge from the street.

While youth unemployment is high here, forty-four percent of the unemployed are college graduates, oil wells gives the country's elites more flexibility when it comes to buying public support, says Gause.
I don't think that there's going to be a direct effect in Saudi Arabia.
I don't think there's going to be revolution tomorrow.
Still, almost every day the government promotes another new program to create more jobs - programs that have taken on a new urgency in the wake of Tunisia and Egypt.
The future is underway, says Gause.
I certainly think that all the Gulf state leaders are preparing for a post-Mubarak Middle East.
The authoritarians systems of the Gulf would be shaken by Mubarak's departure, he says.
But Egypt's president leads an entire system of government that includes a powerful army, a security service and elite who want to continue to benefit from the system as it is.
If Mubarak goes, but the regime in general stays, I don't think that's a big deal for the Gulf states.
If the whole regime comes down and is replaced by something completely different, then the Middle East is a changed place.
Deborah Amos, NPR News, Riyadh.
The legendary singer known as Mama Africa has died.
Miriam Makeba spent decades in exile singing songs of freedom for South Africa.
She was far from home when she suffered a heart attack after a concert in Italy.
NPR's Ofeibea Quist-Arcton has this remembrance.
(Soundbite of song ""Pata Pata"")
(Singing) Sat wuguga sat ju benga sat si pata pat.
Sat wuguga sat ju benga sat si pata pat.

The distinctive voice of Miriam Makeba with the hit song ""Pata Pata."" She embodied the pan-Africanist spirit of the 1960s when she burst onto the international stage and unwittingly became the voice of the anti-apartheid struggle back home in South Africa.
On tour in the U.S., Makeba was banned from returning home for criticizing apartheid.
She was just 27 at the time and wouldn't see South Africa again for more than 30 years, she told NPR in an interview in 2006.
(Soundbite of NPR interview, 2006)
I use a fork and take a bite.
The noodles have just the right amount of crunch, and the restaurant's secret gravy recipe offers a nice counterpoint to the crispy noodles.
It's a warm and comforting sandwich.
Dave Lussier grew up eating chow mein sandwiches with his family in Fall River, and he says it's the noodles that set them apart.
Well, that's what's puzzling to me to hear you report this because I haven't thought of airports as good places to shop.
I always think, well, the prices are going to be too high there and the merchandise is very limited.
But maybe I haven't realized how much airports have changed.
That's right.
In the past, you would buy a $2 package of gum or the best souvenir you could find might have been a shot glass.
You can still buy shot glasses, but more and more airports are really beginning to look like malls.
In fact, I tell people, why go to the mall when you're going to be at the airport anyway?
Well, you're a travel writer.
When did this change take place that I just somehow haven't noticed over the years, and why?
Well, a lot of it has happened since 9/11.

So many people were not traveling after 9/11 that airports really needed to do something different for the people who were traveling to earn more income and to really provide more service for travelers.
You live in Seattle.
I do.

Our producer, Sarah Spivak, told me that you told her you would actually fly to Portland, Oregon, which isn't very far away, but still, you would fly there just to go shopping at the Portland Airport.
I would.
And I have.
And here is why - because in Oregon, there is no sales tax.
And also, in that airport - and I think this is happening in other airports too - they've got branches of all the best local stores out at the airport.
So it's a very convenient place to go.
I don't have to park.
I could just go and go to Powell's, which is the best local bookstore - go to the Made in Oregon store which has things made from everywhere throughout the state.
And there's a Pendleton shop there.
So absolutely, I would go there, get back on the plane and come home.
Harriet Baskas writes about airports and air travel for USAToday.com and MSNBC.com.
Harriet, good - really, useful travel tips today, thank you so much.
See you at the airport.
From the studios of NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
Coming up, one teenager's reaction to the Mitchell Report on steroid use by Major League Baseball players.
First though, it's a late night in Bali, Indonesia, where U.S., European and other leaders are wrapping up their negotiations on climate change.
The countries are trying to break a deadlock over reductions in greenhouse gases.
Yesterday, Al Gore said this.
My own country, the United States, is principally responsible for obstructing progress here in Bali.
(Soundbite of applause)
We all know that.
And for the latest, we go to NPR's Richard Harris, who's also in Bali.
And Richard, what was the reaction to what Al Gore said?
Did it spur further negotiations?
Well, you heard that warm applause that he got.
And yes, negotiations haven't stopped for days and days and days.
So obviously it was one more piece of wait in the hopper to get people to start moving.
And I think that it probably did add extra pressure on the U.S.
negotiators here to try to play nicer with their European counterparts.
And is what he said true?
Is it true that the United States is obstructing any kind of negotiation, any kind of treaty?
Well, any kind of treaty, it may be an exaggeration.
The U.S.
came to Bali with a very defined idea of what they wanted to have.
They wanted to come out of here with a treaty that would essentially be a roadmap for a real treaty in two years' time, sort of rules for negotiating the treaty coming up.
And the U.S.
wanted to have it as simple as possible, as few rules as possible.
And so they came in and they've kept trying to take stuff out that people wanted to have in there.
And they said, well, you can negotiate that later.
You can negotiate that later.
But other people said, no, we want to have a clear sense of where we're going to end up in two years' time.
So that's the tension that has been running through this meeting.
And Richard, the Europeans were threatening to boycott a meeting next month in Hawaii, organized by the White House.
Did that pressure the Americans to go back to the negotiating table?
Yeah.

I think that really got their attention because George Bush is trying to create a separate mechanism for dealing with climate change by inviting just a small number of key nations - economic powerhouses - to join a smaller discussions and see if they can work things out.
At least that's the concept behind the talks.
The first meeting in September didn't seem to produce very much at all.
And they said, well, let's try again in January in Hawaii.
So the Europeans said if we don't get something we like out of Bali, we're not going to Hawaii.
So that really changed the tone of what was happening here.

Now, I also understand that it's not just the United States, it's also the main negotiating bloc of developing countries - the so-called G77 - who are saying, no, we are going to resist any pressure to cut emissions from fossil fuels.
So they too are resisting change.

Well, everybody comes to the table with an agenda, and the G77 definitely has a sense that they want to make sure that the developed world really puts on the table very serious emissions cuts before they would consider even discussing the possibility of cutting their own emissions in the future.
They are getting things out of this, though, because there are actually quite a number of other elements of this that have been agreed to that are really good for the developing world.
For example, there's the makings of a new treaty on forest preservation.
Countries like Indonesia might actually get paid money for not chopping down their forests.
And where are the negotiations in terms of reducing emissions?
What are the targets that look realistic now?
Well, that's part of the - sort of the odd feeling of being at these talks, that they're negotiating numbers that seem impossible to reach anyway.

But on the other hand, if you look at the science of global climate change, you realize that those are the numbers that we really ought to be trying to reach for if we don't want the planet to get a whole lot hotter than it is now.
So it's a really conundrum.
NPR's Richard Harris in Bali.
Thank you very much.
